content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Once thought of as only a toxic by-product of cellular metabolism, the chemical hydrogen peroxide (<math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math>) is now known to play an integral role in maintaining cell homeostasis. Recent research suggests that <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> is one of a small group of molecules that can be transported across the plasma membrane through aquaporins, where it can affect cell signaling. To investigate the transport of <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> through aquaporins, researchers made four different groups of liposomes (spherical vesicles surrounded by a phospholipid bilayer). One group of liposomes was constructed as a simple vesicle of phospholipids (group <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>). Into the phospholipid bilayer of the three other groups of liposomes, researchers embedded either a type of human aquaporin (group <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>) or one of two types of plant aquaporin (groups <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> and <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></math>). The rate at which <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> was transported into the liposomes of each group was then determined (Table 1). TABLE 1. RATE OF HYDROGEN PEROXIDE TRANSPORT INTO LIPOSOMES Group Type of Aquaporin Embedded in Liposome Phospholipid Bilayer Average Rate of <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> Transport (<math alttext="microliters per second, plus or minus 2, times S E sub x bar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>μL/s ± 2SE</mtext><mover accent="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover></msub></math> ) <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> None <math alttext="0.9 plus or minus 0.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.9</mn><mo> </mo><mo>±</mo><mo> </mo><mn>0.1</mn></math> <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> Human <math alttext="1.4 plus or minus 0.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.4</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.1</mn></math> <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> Plant <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math> <math alttext="1.7 plus or minus 0.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.7</mn><mo> </mo><mo>±</mo><mo> </mo><mn>0.1</mn></math> <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></math> Plant <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>II</mtext></math> <math alttext="1.8 plus or minus 0.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.8</mn><mo> </mo><mo>±</mo><mo> </mo><mn>0.1</mn></math> Figure 1 shows a simplified model of the relationship between <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> concentration and an intracellular signaling pathway. When the concentration of <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> is low, the enzyme <math alttext="T p x 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Tpx</mi><mn>1</mn></math> is active, leading to the activation of the transcription factor <math alttext="P a p 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Pap</mi><mn>1</mn></math> in a reaction that consumes <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math>. Once activated, <math alttext="P a p 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Pap</mi><mn>1</mn></math> moves to the nucleus, where it can activate transcription of a group of <math alttext="P a p 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Pap</mi><mn>1</mn></math>-regulated genes. As the concentration of <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> starts to increase, <math alttext="T p x 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Tpx</mi><mn>1</mn></math> becomes inactivated, allowing for even more <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> to accumulate, because it is no longer consumed in the activation of <math alttext="P a p 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Pap</mi><mn>1</mn></math>. The accumulation of <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> leads to the activation of the enzyme <math alttext="S t y 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Sty</mi><mn>1</mn></math>, which then activates transcription factor <math alttext="A t f 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Atf</mi><mn>1</mn></math>. <math alttext="A t f 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Atf</mi><mn>1</mn></math> moves to the nucleus and activates transcription of a group of <math alttext="A t f 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Atf</mi><mn>1</mn></math>-regulated genes. Figure 1. Simplified model of a signaling pathway involving <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> at both low (A) and high (B) intracellular concentrations of <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> (a) Describe the advantage to a cell of having aquaporins when the substances that pass directly through aquaporins can also pass through the phospholipid bilayer.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Once thought of as only a toxic by-product of cellular metabolism, the chemical hydrogen peroxide (<math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math>) is now known to play an integral role in maintaining cell homeostasis. Recent research suggests that <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> is one of a small group of molecules that can be transported across the plasma membrane through aquaporins, where it can affect cell signaling. To investigate the transport of <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> through aquaporins, researchers made four different groups of liposomes (spherical vesicles surrounded by a phospholipid bilayer). One group of liposomes was constructed as a simple vesicle of phospholipids (group <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>). Into the phospholipid bilayer of the three other groups of liposomes, researchers embedded either a type of human aquaporin (group <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>) or one of two types of plant aquaporin (groups <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> and <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></math>). The rate at which <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> was transported into the liposomes of each group was then determined (Table 1). TABLE 1. RATE OF HYDROGEN PEROXIDE TRANSPORT INTO LIPOSOMES Group Type of Aquaporin Embedded in Liposome Phospholipid Bilayer Average Rate of <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> Transport (<math alttext="microliters per second, plus or minus 2, times S E sub x bar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>μL/s ± 2SE</mtext><mover accent="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover></msub></math> ) <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> None <math alttext="0.9 plus or minus 0.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.9</mn><mo> </mo><mo>±</mo><mo> </mo><mn>0.1</mn></math> <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> Human <math alttext="1.4 plus or minus 0.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.4</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.1</mn></math> <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> Plant <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math> <math alttext="1.7 plus or minus 0.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.7</mn><mo> </mo><mo>±</mo><mo> </mo><mn>0.1</mn></math> <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></math> Plant <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>II</mtext></math> <math alttext="1.8 plus or minus 0.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.8</mn><mo> </mo><mo>±</mo><mo> </mo><mn>0.1</mn></math> Figure 1 shows a simplified model of the relationship between <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> concentration and an intracellular signaling pathway. When the concentration of <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> is low, the enzyme <math alttext="T p x 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Tpx</mi><mn>1</mn></math> is active, leading to the activation of the transcription factor <math alttext="P a p 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Pap</mi><mn>1</mn></math> in a reaction that consumes <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math>. Once activated, <math alttext="P a p 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Pap</mi><mn>1</mn></math> moves to the nucleus, where it can activate transcription of a group of <math alttext="P a p 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Pap</mi><mn>1</mn></math>-regulated genes. As the concentration of <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> starts to increase, <math alttext="T p x 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Tpx</mi><mn>1</mn></math> becomes inactivated, allowing for even more <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> to accumulate, because it is no longer consumed in the activation of <math alttext="P a p 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Pap</mi><mn>1</mn></math>. The accumulation of <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> leads to the activation of the enzyme <math alttext="S t y 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Sty</mi><mn>1</mn></math>, which then activates transcription factor <math alttext="A t f 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Atf</mi><mn>1</mn></math>. <math alttext="A t f 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Atf</mi><mn>1</mn></math> moves to the nucleus and activates transcription of a group of <math alttext="A t f 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Atf</mi><mn>1</mn></math>-regulated genes. Figure 1. Simplified model of a signaling pathway involving <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> at both low (A) and high (B) intracellular concentrations of <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> (a) Describe the advantage to a cell of having aquaporins when the substances that pass directly through aquaporins can also pass through the phospholipid bilayer.

(b) Using the template in the space provided for your response, construct an appropriately labeled graph that represents the data in Table 1. Determine the type(s) of aquaporins that transport(s) <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> at a rate that is different from the rate at which the plant type <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>II</mtext></math> aquaporins transport <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math>.

(c) Based on the data in Table 1, identify the rate in <math alttext="microliters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>μL</mi><mo>/</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math> at which <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> can be transported by simple diffusion through the phospholipid bilayer. Calculate the difference between the average microliters of <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> transported into group <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> liposomes in five minutes and the average microliters of <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> transported into group <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> liposomes in five minutes.

(d) An enzyme called <math alttext="S r x 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Srx</mi><mn>1</mn></math> is required for the activation of <math alttext="T p x 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Tpx</mi><mn>1</mn></math>. Researchers identified a mutation that results in a nonfunctional form of <math alttext="S r x 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Srx</mi><mn>1</mn></math>. Based on the model in Figure 1, predict the effect of this nonfunctional <math alttext="S r x 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Srx</mi><mn>1</mn></math> on the expression of <math alttext="P a p 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Pap</mi><mn>1</mn></math>-regulated genes AND <math alttext="A t f 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Atf</mi><mn>1</mn></math>-regulated genes. Provide reasoning to justify your prediction.
